text: And there was set  meat before him to eat: but he said, I will not eat, until I have told mine errand. And he said, Speak on.
text_kjv: And there was set  meat before him to eat: but he said, I will not eat, until I have told mine errand. And he said, Speak on.
text_niv: Then food was set before him, but he said, “I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say.”“Then tell us,” Laban said.
text_esv: Then food was set before him to eat. But he said, “I will not eat until I have said what I have to say.” He said, “Speak on.”
text_nlt: Then food was served. But Abraham’s servant said, “I don’t want to eat until I have told you why I have come.” “All right,” Laban said, “tell us.”
text_msg: Then Laban brought out food. But the man said, "I won't eat until I tell my story."Laban said, "Go ahead; tell us."
text_nasb: But when [food] was set before him to eat, he said, 'I will not eat until I have told my business.' And he said, 'Speak on.'
context: Genesis 24 recounts Abraham's meticulous plan to secure a wife for his son Isaac from among his own people, away from the Canaanites. The servant, likely Eliezer of Damascus (though unnamed), undertakes a long journey to Mesopotamia, armed with gifts and specific instructions. His arrival at the well, his prayer for divine guidance, and the subsequent encounter with Rebekah, are pivotal. The setting, a well outside a city, was a crucial gathering point for women who drew water, offering opportunities for interaction and information exchange. Hospitality was a sacred duty in ancient Near Eastern cultures. Offering food and lodging to travelers was not merely polite; it was a societal obligation deeply rooted in the harsh realities of nomadic life and the reliance on mutual aid. Refusal to offer hospitality was a grave offense, potentially endangering the traveler's life. The detailed account of the gifts the servant presented to Rebekah and her family reflects the importance of dowry and the negotiation involved in marriage arrangements. The verse's mention of "meat" highlights the significance of meat as a luxury, not an everyday staple, further emphasizing the host's generosity and desire to honor the guest. The emphasis on Abraham's instructions underscores the patriarchal structure of the society, where fathers held significant authority in arranging their children's marriages. The servant's urgency to fulfill his mission and his deferral of food demonstrate his deep commitment to his master and to God's providence.
meaning: This verse reveals much about the servant's character and his understanding of his role as an instrument in God's plan. His refusal to eat before conveying his message is not merely about politeness; it demonstrates a profound sense of duty, urgency, and reverence. He prioritizes the task entrusted to him by Abraham and ultimately by God over his own physical needs. His statement, "I will not eat, until I have told mine errand," highlights his commitment to integrity and his desire to be faithful to his master's instructions. This prioritization reflects a spiritual maturity and a recognition that he is acting as an ambassador for Abraham and, more importantly, as an instrument of God's will. The phrase "mine errand" emphasizes the seriousness and importance he attaches to his mission. The host's immediate response, "Speak on," reflects the culture's emphasis on hospitality and willingness to listen to the traveler's story. It also suggests an understanding that the servant's refusal to eat was unusual and indicated a matter of considerable importance. This exchange underscores the tension between cultural norms (hospitality) and divine purpose (fulfilling God's will). The servant's actions can be interpreted as a model for believers, demonstrating the importance of placing God's priorities above personal comfort and desires. His obedience and commitment foreshadow the obedience of Christ and the dedication required of those who follow Him.
application: In modern life, this verse offers a powerful lesson in prioritization, integrity, and commitment. The servant's example challenges us to examine our own lives and identify the "errands" that God has entrusted to us. Are we prioritizing these tasks over our own comfort and desires? Do we approach our responsibilities with a sense of urgency and dedication, or do we allow distractions and self-interest to hinder our progress? In the context of work, this verse encourages us to approach our tasks with diligence and a commitment to excellence, prioritizing the needs of our clients and colleagues over our own personal gain. In our families, it challenges us to put the needs of our spouse and children before our own, even when it requires sacrifice and inconvenience. In our spiritual lives, this verse reminds us to prioritize our relationship with God, setting aside time for prayer, Bible study, and service to others, even when we are busy or tired. We can apply this by setting clear goals, focusing on one task at a time, and resisting the temptation to procrastinate or be distracted. By emulating the servant's unwavering commitment to his mission, we can become more effective instruments in God's hands. It also calls for recognizing opportunities that God puts in our path and being willing to embrace those opportunities regardless of personal comfort. Consider how the servant's behavior also models efficient communication and clarity – he understands the brevity of time and importance of getting to the point. We should strive to communicate with others effectively and purposefully.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the example of the servant in Genesis 24. His dedication and commitment inspire me to prioritize your will above my own desires. Forgive me for the times when I have allowed comfort and convenience to distract me from the tasks you have given me. Grant me the strength and discipline to focus on your "errands" with urgency and diligence. Help me to be a faithful steward of the gifts and opportunities you have entrusted to me. Guide me to recognize the needs of others and to serve them with a selfless heart. May my life be a testament to your love and grace. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The servant refused to eat because he prioritized completing his mission for Abraham. He felt a sense of urgency to secure a wife for Isaac before attending to his personal needs, demonstrating dedication and reverence for his task.

faqs.answer: This verse highlights the cultural importance of hospitality. Offering food, especially meat, to a traveler was a significant gesture of welcome and protection, reflecting a societal obligation to care for strangers.
